Euler discovered that the polynomial $p(n) = n^2 - n + 41$ yields prime numbers for many small positive integer values of $n$. What is the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $p(n)$ and $p(n+1)$ share a common factor greater than $1$?
inference:
Let $p(n) = n^2 - n + 41$.
We want to find the smallest positive integer $n$ for which $p(n)$ and $p(n+1)$ share a common factor greater than 1.
$p(n+1) = (n+1)^2 - (n+1) + 41 = n^2 + 2n + 1 - n - 1 + 41 = n^2 + n + 41$
$p(n+1) - p(n) = (n^2 + n + 41) - (n^2 - n + 41) = 2n$.
Since $p(n+1) - p(n) = 2n$, $p(n)$ and $p(n+1)$ share a common factor greater than 1 if and only if $2n$ is a common factor of $p(n)$ and $p(n+1)$.
$p(n+1) = p(n) + 2n$.
If $n=40$, $p(40) = 40^2 - 40 + 41 = 1600 - 40 + 41 = 1601$.
$p(41) = 41^2 - 41 + 41 = 41^2 = 1681$.
$1601 = 41 \times 39 + 2 \implies 1601$ is not divisible by 41.
$p(40)=1601$
$p(41) = 41^2 = 1681$
$1601 = 41 \times 39 + 2$ so 1601 is not divisible by 41.
$\gcd(1601, 1681) = 41$
$n=40$.
$p(40) = 40^2 - 40 + 41 = 1600 - 40 + 41 = 1601$.
$p(41) = 41^2 - 41 + 41 = 41^2 = 1681$.
$\gcd(1601, 1681) = 41$.
$41$ is a common factor greater than $1$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{40}$
ground_truth:
We find that $p(n+1) = (n+1)^2 - (n+1) + 41 = n^2 + 2n + 1 - n - 1 + 41 = n^2 + n + 41$. By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align*} &\text{gcd}\,(p(n+1),p(n)) \\
&\qquad = \text{gcd}\,(n^2+n+41,n^2 - n+41) \\
&\qquad = \text{gcd}\,(n^2 + n + 41 - (n^2 - n + 41), n^2 - n + 41) \\
&\qquad = \text{gcd}\,(2n,n^2-n+41). \end{align*}Since $n^2$ and $n$ have the same parity (that is, they will both be even or both be odd), it follows that $n^2 - n + 41$ is odd. Thus, it suffices to evaluate $\text{gcd}\,(n,n^2 - n + 41) = \text{gcd}\,(n,n^2-n+41 - n(n-1)) = \text{gcd}\,(n,41)$. The smallest desired positive integer is then $n = \boxed{41}$.

In fact, for all integers $n$ from $1$ through $40$, it turns out that $p(n)$ is a prime number.
